"However, it so happens that the
Constitution does not contain the answers to these problems because of
its very vague and ambiguous
language. Consequently, the unconstitutionality of the New Deal, for example, is not due to the Constitution, but due to the opinion of judges
as to what they think the Constitution ought to mean. Most of these
problems could have been settled
either way; and, if a conservative
court decides them in a conservative
way, it must assume the responsibilitl for its choice."
Mr. Sachs suggested that many
people insist that the President
should seek his reforms through a
constitutional amendment, but he
thinks that the President could reply that "the Constitution is adequate.
It is not the Constitution that needs
amending but the Supreme Court."
Discounting the President's humanitarian motives, Mr. Sachs declared that far from easing the burden of the older justices, the measure would increase it, because among
othr things it authorizes that all
cases in lower court declaring an
act of Congress unconstitutional be
immediately heard in the Supreme
Court. A great majority of cases
never reach the "nine old men."
"I favor the Supreme Court's retaining its present function of judicial review," Mr. Sachs asserted, "but
I favor a constitutional amendment
that would authorize Congress to
repass legislation declared unconstitutional by the Court by a two-thirds
majority. This is certainly a conservative enough check on hasty legislation."

is under voting age. However, the

age, while now they are twenty-one,
shows that our nation has become law
enforcement conscious, and that there
is no longer any hero-worship of
criminals by youth. The desirable effect is apparent.

Billy Igaac Band To Play
At Musical Club Concert

Returns from the ballots sent out
by the June Week committee to the
Senior Class show that eighty per
cent of those who replied favored the
continuation of the annual June Week.
Seventy-five per cent of the graduating class replied to the questionnaire
distributed.
Roy Galloway, president of the
class, issued the following statement
upon complete tabulation of returns:
"I am very pleased with the response
of my colleagues to the appeal of the
June Week committee, and I am sure

that with the support which has been
promised us we will be able to make
a success of June Week, financially
as well as socially."
Average Price
The ballot showed that the average
of the class was in favor of a price of
ten dollars per person for the entire
week. Last year the price was twelve
dollars per person. The result of last
year's June Week was that there was
a full week of activity, with the Senior Ball, Junior Prom, Night Club
Party, Tea Dances, and other events.
The June Week festivities take place
during the first week after exams, in
order to finish off the school year with
a memorable celebration.
James Bradford, chairman of the
committee, stated that he would appoint a large group to assist him in
making the necessary arrangements,
such as bands, halls, and other things
incidental to its success.

Strinberg Festival
Play To Follow Dr. Miller's Lecture
On Playwright Next
Tuesday Evening
The Playshop-sponsored Strindberg
Festival will get under way next Tuesday, with an evening devoted to a lecture and play. The lecture will be
delivered by Dr. Anne Irena Millere,
professor of English at Goucher College, on the subject, "August Strindberg, the Father of Expression." Following this, Director N. B. Fagin announces, will be presented the play,
"First Warning," by Strindberg.

By Bobby Hildreth
On Friday, February 26, at 8.15 the
enjoyment of five and one-half hours
will get under way at the Maryland
Casualty Auditorium. The ball of
good time will start rolling with the
various departments of the club presenting their achievements from past
rehearsals. This includes the Glee
Club, Banjo Club, Hawaiian Troupe,
Quartette, Blue Jay orchestra and
soloists who will render a few "bars
in search of melody." This part of the
program should conclude about 10.15,
but then it is only the beginning.

The total price has been set at $3
per couple. This includes the concert,
which is $1 per person unless an
S.A.C. card is exchanged for a complimentary ticket; while the dance is
$1 per couple for everybody. Let's
support the affair.

This band has played jobs out of

"China Goes Modern"
Is Topic Of Lecture
Mr. Eugene E. Barnett, founder of
the Hangchow Y.M.C.A., considered
one of the largest and most influential
in China, addressed a joint committee of the Cosmopolitan Club and the
Friendly Relations Committee of the
"Y" on his favorite subject, "China
Goes Modern," at 4:00 p.m. yesterday
in Levering Hall.
Mr. Barnett, a graduate of Emory
University, has spent 26 years in
China, and has recently been elected
director of World Service of United
States and Canada.

Doug Meigs seems to be •having
trouble with his "Bug." That is the
little green Austin you see parked
about the campus. His friends seem
to enjoy hiding it from him while he
attends classes. This week he found it
in the woods near the power house.
Why not take it to class with you,
Doug?

MUSICANA
Alexandre Scriabin, music's sole
mystic, is a great musician, but he is
greatly neglected. Tuesday night, a
group of Baltimorean music-lovers
gathered to hear the National Symphony play his 3rd Symphony, Le
Divin Poeme. It was an unforgettable
experience. Exotic harmonies, shimmering solo passages, brilliant orchestral coloring were mixed with a
wild overpowering emotional appeal.
One still remembers the huge, shattering, forte-fortissmo in the first
movement, the melodious violin solo,
with flute chirping in the second, and
the unrestrained, lusty, final shout of
joy. Undoubtedly a great work, even
at second hearing, it leads one to wait
with anticipation future hearings of
the works of this strange, bizarre
philosopher.

Capt. Kokie Of Mt.St. Mary's
Chalks Up 15 Points
As High Scorer
A fast moving, fast breaking Mt.
st. Mary's quintet defeated Johns
Hopkins last Tuesday evening at
tnunitsburg to score their sixth
league victory. The Galloping Saints
functioned smoothly enough to erase
ally doubt as to their superiority in
the Maryland Intercollegiate League.
The final score of the contest, played
before an aroused crowd of hoop fans,
was 41-19.
Fast First Half
The play during the first half was
eaPecially fast, with the Blue Jay
quick break on tap-off and pick-off
Plays working as the main phase of
the attack. The Malloneemen emPloyed the zone defense throughout
the battle and were well nigh imPregnable at times, altho the better
hall handling of the home team enabled them to break through to score,
When catching the Jays unawares.
It should be stated that a strong
Hopkins defense kept down the home
team scoring during the first period,
but were unable to stop the Mountmen
NM coming through during the 5ec011(1 canto. Hopkins took the lead at
the offset with a 3-2 margin, but a
leng toss by Kokie, the Mount captain, dissolved this, and the visitors
Were never threatened seriously since
that incident. Apichella was the chief
threat during the scoring rampage
that followed, scoring 8 of the 15
Points that his team scored for that
Priod. Siegel's two field goals, reinforced by numerous fouls thrown by
the Jays, set the Black and Blue
tharkers at 8.
Sad Second Half
The last half was decisive as the
turning point, for the home team
cored 26 points to the 11 counters
for Johns Hopkins. In this section of
the contest, Kokie, guard and the outStanding man on the floor, went wild
to pull his scoring total up to 15
Points for the evening. His handling
ef the ball was a beautiful thing to
Watch, and his passing was responsible for the defeat of the Hopkins zone
defense in the latter phase of the
4frair.
Hopping Herby Siegel was the
Hopkins high scorer with a total of
Points, made on 4 field goals.

game . . . the clever Hopkins defense in the first half . . . Siegel's

a last ray of hope. . . Dimmy Tragkia running around big Frank Apich'lla on a lay up . . . the number of
roul shots taken . ..

The Black and Blue natators( led
by Captain Danny Weiner, turned
down the University of Maryland
swimming team by the score of 3929 in a closely contested meet at the
Shoreham Hotel pool, Washington,
D.C., last Monday evening.
Last Event Decisive
The meet was undecided until the
last event, the 400 yard relay, in
which every man swam even, until
Zoel Radner, the anchor man, sprinted
to give 'Hopkins the race and meet.
The next opponents of the Blue Jay
aggregation will be Lehigh who will
be met Saturday, 3 P.M. at the Baltimore City College Pool. It has been
many years since Hopkins can boast
of such a club as this year's. A request
for a larger turnout at the meets has
been made to the student body by the
team and Coach Hambleton.

follows:

With four weeks remaining of frat
basketball, Kappa Alpha and Pi
Lambda are knotted for top honors
in division A while Phi Gamma Delta
threatens to run away in the other
division. All these squads copped conl.ests Saturday. K.S.. defeated the
Phi Sigma Delta crew, and Pi Lam
Epsilon
Pi
its fourth
handed
defeat. The other leader, Phi Gamma
Delta, also won in a low scoring contest with Phi Alpha. Only seven field
goals were netted by both teams with
Phi Gam tallying four to nose out
the P. A. five 8-6.
D. U. Versus PI Lams
Delta Upsilon conquered Kappa Alpha to remain in the pennant race.
After a hard fought match, K. A.
dropped the game 18-10. The D. U.
and Pi Lam courtmen are closely
matched in points towards the frat
token, and both are trying to secure
the basketball crown to strengthen
their claim to the award. On Saturday, February 20, Kappa Sigma will
meet the Delta Upsilon representatives. Even at this date, this battle
will be important in deciding the
title.

The
Hopkins handball varsity
caught the Police A. C. flatfooted
Thursday night in a hard fought
strugggle by a score of 4-1. The handballers took the police in their stride,
in prelude to the big match this
week-end with the University of Virginia at Homewood.
Milberg Wins
In the first singles match, Iry
Milberg defeated Jos. Alexander by
a score of 15-5, 10-15, 15-2. In the
second singles match Dick Pasternak
followed up with another victory over
Ed Parr to the tune of 21-15, 15-6.
In the third singles, Milt Alperstein
completed the sweep of the singles
matches by taking over Al. Sennet,
15-8, 15-5.
In the double matches, Iry Milberg paired with Dick Pasternak to
trounce the Police team of Lowrey
Rogers and Bob Rice, 15-8, 15-8.
However, Captain Nat Finkelstein
and Joe Hernandez were tripped up
by John Burns and George Kleimik
by a score of 15-13, 12-15, 15-9. A
return match is being arranged for a
later date.

Peoples of ancient times had types
of personal identification, such as
branding, mutilation and Somatic
measurement. However, China was
already using thumb prints in business. By 1850, it was discovered in
Europe that the characteristic marks
on finger hubs could not be removed
by mutilation.
Scotland Yard set up a fingerprint filing system in 1901. In 1924
the United States set up its fingerprint clearing house in Washington.
It now has the prints of some six million people, ten of each. 4,000 prints
a day come pouring in, but an average of 52 out of 100 are already on
file. When fingerprints of a suspicious
character are sent to Washington, in
less than five minutes his prints and
record, if on file, may be found. This
record helps in the giving of a sentence in keeping with the type of
criminal. It is also useful in amnesia
cases.

"However, it so happens that the
Constitution does not contain the answers to these problems because of
its very vague and ambiguous
language. Consequently, the unconstitutionality of the New Deal, for example, is not due to the Constitution, but due to the opinion of judges
as to what they think the Constitution ought to mean. Most of these
problems could have been settled
either way; and, if a conservative
court decides them in a conservative
way, it must assume the responsibilitl for its choice."
Mr. Sachs suggested that many
people insist that the President
should seek his reforms through a
constitutional amendment, but he
thinks that the President could reply that "the Constitution is adequate.
It is not the Constitution that needs
amending but the Supreme Court."
Discounting the President's humanitarian motives, Mr. Sachs declared that far from easing the burden of the older justices, the measure would increase it, because among
othr things it authorizes that all
cases in lower court declaring an
act of Congress unconstitutional be
immediately heard in the Supreme
Court. A great majority of cases
never reach the "nine old men."
"I favor the Supreme Court's retaining its present function of judicial review," Mr. Sachs asserted, "but
I favor a constitutional amendment
that would authorize Congress to
repass legislation declared unconstitutional by the Court by a two-thirds
majority. This is certainly a conservative enough check on hasty legislation."

Billy Igaac Band To Play
At Musical Club Concert

Returns from the ballots sent out
by the June Week committee to the
Senior Class show that eighty per
cent of those who replied favored the
continuation of the annual June Week.
Seventy-five per cent of the graduating class replied to the questionnaire
distributed.
Roy Galloway, president of the
class, issued the following statement
upon complete tabulation of returns:
"I am very pleased with the response
of my colleagues to the appeal of the
June Week committee, and I am sure

that with the support which has been
promised us we will be able to make
a success of June Week, financially
as well as socially."
Average Price
The ballot showed that the average
of the class was in favor of a price of
ten dollars per person for the entire
week. Last year the price was twelve
dollars per person. The result of last
year's June Week was that there was
a full week of activity, with the Senior Ball, Junior Prom, Night Club
Party, Tea Dances, and other events.
The June Week festivities take place
during the first week after exams, in
order to finish off the school year with
a memorable celebration.
James Bradford, chairman of the
committee, stated that he would appoint a large group to assist him in
making the necessary arrangements,
such as bands, halls, and other things
incidental to its success.

The Playshop-sponsored Strindberg
Festival will get under way next Tuesday, with an evening devoted to a lecture and play. The lecture will be

professor of English at Goucher College, on the subject, "August Strindberg, the Father of Expression." Following this, Director N. B. Fagin announces, will be presented the play,
"First Warning," by Strindberg.

"China Goes Modern"
Is Topic Of Lecture
Mr. Eugene E. Barnett, founder of
the Hangchow Y.M.C.A., considered
one of the largest and most influential
in China, addressed a joint committee of the Cosmopolitan Club and the
Friendly Relations Committee of the
"Y" on his favorite subject, "China
Goes Modern," at 4:00 p.m. yesterday
in Levering Hall.
Mr. Barnett, a graduate of Emory
University, has spent 26 years in
China, and has recently been elected
director of World Service of United
States and Canada.

about the campus. His friends seem

Why not take it to class with you,

MUSICANA
Alexandre Scriabin, music's sole
mystic, is a great musician, but he is
greatly neglected. Tuesday night, a
group of Baltimorean music-lovers
gathered to hear the National Symphony play his 3rd Symphony, Le
Divin Poeme. It was an unforgettable
experience. Exotic harmonies, shimmering solo passages, brilliant orchestral coloring were mixed with a
wild overpowering emotional appeal.
One still remembers the huge, shattering, forte-fortissmo in the first
movement, the melodious violin solo,
with flute chirping in the second, and
the unrestrained, lusty, final shout of
joy. Undoubtedly a great work, even
at second hearing, it leads one to wait
with anticipation future hearings of
the works of this strange, bizarre
philosopher.

Capt. Kokie Of Mt.St. Mary's
Chalks Up 15 Points
As High Scorer
A fast moving, fast breaking Mt.
st. Mary's quintet defeated Johns
Hopkins last Tuesday evening at
tnunitsburg to score their sixth
league victory. The Galloping Saints
functioned smoothly enough to erase
ally doubt as to their superiority in
the Maryland Intercollegiate League.
The final score of the contest, played
before an aroused crowd of hoop fans,
was 41-19.
Fast First Half
The play during the first half was
eaPecially fast, with the Blue Jay
quick break on tap-off and pick-off
Plays working as the main phase of
the attack. The Malloneemen emPloyed the zone defense throughout
the battle and were well nigh imPregnable at times, altho the better
hall handling of the home team enabled them to break through to score,
When catching the Jays unawares.
It should be stated that a strong
Hopkins defense kept down the home
team scoring during the first period,
but were unable to stop the Mountmen
NM coming through during the 5ec011(1 canto. Hopkins took the lead at
the offset with a 3-2 margin, but a
leng toss by Kokie, the Mount captain, dissolved this, and the visitors
Were never threatened seriously since
that incident. Apichella was the chief
threat during the scoring rampage
that followed, scoring 8 of the 15
Points that his team scored for that
Priod. Siegel's two field goals, reinforced by numerous fouls thrown by
the Jays, set the Black and Blue
tharkers at 8.
Sad Second Half
The last half was decisive as the
turning point, for the home team
cored 26 points to the 11 counters
for Johns Hopkins. In this section of
the contest, Kokie, guard and the outStanding man on the floor, went wild
to pull his scoring total up to 15
Points for the evening. His handling
ef the ball was a beautiful thing to
Watch, and his passing was responsible for the defeat of the Hopkins zone
defense in the latter phase of the
4frair.
Hopping Herby Siegel was the
Hopkins high scorer with a total of
Points, made on 4 field goals.

game . . . the clever Hopkins defense in the first half . . . Siegel's

a last ray of hope. . . Dimmy Tragkia running around big Frank Apich'lla on a lay up . . . the number of
roul shots taken . ..

The Black and Blue natators( led
by Captain Danny Weiner, turned
down the University of Maryland
swimming team by the score of 3929 in a closely contested meet at the
Shoreham Hotel pool, Washington,
D.C., last Monday evening.
Last Event Decisive
The meet was undecided until the
last event, the 400 yard relay, in
which every man swam even, until
Zoel Radner, the anchor man, sprinted
to give 'Hopkins the race and meet.
The next opponents of the Blue Jay
aggregation will be Lehigh who will
be met Saturday, 3 P.M. at the Baltimore City College Pool. It has been
many years since Hopkins can boast
of such a club as this year's. A request
for a larger turnout at the meets has
been made to the student body by the
team and Coach Hambleton.
The results of the contest are as
follows:

With four weeks remaining of frat
basketball, Kappa Alpha and Pi
Lambda are knotted for top honors
in division A while Phi Gamma Delta
threatens to run away in the other
division. All these squads copped conl.ests Saturday. K.S.. defeated the
Phi Sigma Delta crew, and Pi Lam
Epsilon
Pi
its fourth
handed
defeat. The other leader, Phi Gamma
Delta, also won in a low scoring contest with Phi Alpha. Only seven field
goals were netted by both teams with
Phi Gam tallying four to nose out
the P. A. five 8-6.
D. U. Versus PI Lams
Delta Upsilon conquered Kappa Alpha to remain in the pennant race.
After a hard fought match, K. A.
dropped the game 18-10. The D. U.
and Pi Lam courtmen are closely
matched in points towards the frat
token, and both are trying to secure
the basketball crown to strengthen
their claim to the award. On Saturday, February 20, Kappa Sigma will
meet the Delta Upsilon representatives. Even at this date, this battle
will be important in deciding the
title.

The
Hopkins handball varsity
caught the Police A. C. flatfooted
Thursday night in a hard fought
strugggle by a score of 4-1. The handballers took the police in their stride,
in prelude to the big match this
week-end with the University of Virginia at Homewood.
Milberg Wins
In the first singles match, Iry
Milberg defeated Jos. Alexander by
a score of 15-5, 10-15, 15-2. In the
second singles match Dick Pasternak
followed up with another victory over
Ed Parr to the tune of 21-15, 15-6.
In the third singles, Milt Alperstein
completed the sweep of the singles
matches by taking over Al. Sennet,
15-8, 15-5.
In the double matches, Iry Milberg paired with Dick Pasternak to
trounce the Police team of Lowrey
Rogers and Bob Rice, 15-8, 15-8.
However, Captain Nat Finkelstein
and Joe Hernandez were tripped up
by John Burns and George Kleimik
by a score of 15-13, 12-15, 15-9. A
return match is being arranged for a
later date.

Peoples of ancient times had types
of personal identification, such as
branding, mutilation and Somatic
measurement. However, China was
already using thumb prints in business. By 1850, it was discovered in
Europe that the characteristic marks
on finger hubs could not be removed
by mutilation.
Scotland Yard set up a fingerprint filing system in 1901. In 1924
the United States set up its fingerprint clearing house in Washington.
It now has the prints of some six million people, ten of each. 4,000 prints
a day come pouring in, but an average of 52 out of 100 are already on
